docs.snippet: Bond prices continued irregularly lower on the Stock Exchange in yesterday's brief trading period, rail- road bonds again leading the decline. Aside from infrequently traded issues, losses of 1 to 4 points about covered the principal setbacks in the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bond prices continued irregularly lower on the Stock Exchange in yesterday's brief trading period, rail- road bonds again leading the decline. Aside from infrequently traded issues, losses of 1 to 4 points about covered the principal setbacks in the rail issues, which were recorded on comparatively quiet trading.

headline.main: BOND PRICES EASE IN SMALL TURNOVER; Rails Lead Declines, Utilities Are Steady and Issues of Industrials Hold. TRACTIONS HERE IRREGULAR Scandinavian Loans Break Hard -- Belgians Under Pressure -- Federal Securities Off.

docs.snippet: Japanese bonds were under pressure on the Stock Exchange yesterday, losses amounting to 1 to 5 3/4 points in trading that was somewhat heavier than it had been in the preceding few days. The bond market as a whole was lower, with the notable...
docs.lead_paragraph: Japanese bonds were under pressure on the Stock Exchange yesterday, losses amounting to 1 to 5 3/4 points in trading that was somewhat heavier than it had been in the preceding few days. The bond market as a whole was lower, with the notable exception of United States Government securities, which rose briskly 1-32 to 30-32d point with the exception of the Liberty 3 1/2s which held unchanged.

headline.main: JAPAN'S BONDS DIP ON STOCK EXCHANGE; Losses Range From 1 to 5 3/4 Points -- United States Government List Up. URUGUAYAN LOANS FIRMER Utilities, Industrials and Rails Under Pressure in Domestic Corporation Group.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- There was no change in the level of business activity in a majority of the American foreign markets for the second week in January apart from a feeling of optimism for the coming year, according to the weekly survey of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- There was no change in the level of business activity in a majority of the American foreign markets for the second week in January apart from a feeling of optimism for the coming year, according to the weekly survey of the Department of Commerce, which follows in brief.

headline.main: LITTLE GAIN MADE IN TRADE ABROAD; Weekly Survey of Department of Commerce States Conditions Are Unchanged. ARGENTINA IS HOPEFUL Unseasonable Weather Curtails Trade in Canada -- Cuba Reports a Slight Gain.

docs.snippet: GENEVA, Feb. 2 -- Two hundred and thirty-two men and women, representing nearly sixty nations With different traditions, different cultures and different creeds at all ends of the earth, sat facing the presidential tribune when Arthur Henderson this...
docs.lead_paragraph: GENEVA, Feb. 2 -- Two hundred and thirty-two men and women, representing nearly sixty nations With different traditions, different cultures and different creeds at all ends of the earth, sat facing the presidential tribune when Arthur Henderson this afternoon opened the proceedings of the first world conference on disarmament.

headline.main: ARMS PARLEY OPENS WITH PLEA TO HEED DESIRE OF PEOPLES; Henderson Tells Delegates That 1,700,000,000 Seek Relief From Burdens of War. SESSION DELAYED 2 HOURS League Council Meeting on Far Eastern Situation Stresses Urgency of Conferees' Task. HENDERSON OPENS ARMS CONFERENCE

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Life insurance in force throughout the world at the close of 1929 aggregated $147,000,000,000 and incomplete data for 1930 indicate a "substantial increase" in that year, according to a survey by A.S. Christenson, made public...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Life insurance in force throughout the world at the close of 1929 aggregated $147,000,000,000 and incomplete data for 1930 indicate a "substantial increase" in that year, according to a survey by A.S. Christenson, made public today by the Department of Commerce.
docs.abstract: 1929 ins in force in world aggregates $147,000, 000,000

headline.main: 1929 LIFE INSURANCE 147 BILLION IN WORLD; Incomplete Data for 1930 Show Gains in 17 of 22 Countries and Sharp Increase in Some. AMERICA FAR IN THE LEAD Policies Here Totaled $107,948,278,- 000 at the End of 1930 -- Britain Was Next With $12,874,985,000.
